title: 114_s2618
content: The Act titled "Medicaid Directory of Caregivers Act" or "Medicaid DOC Act" requires the publication of a fee-for-service provider directory. The "Medicaid Directory of Caregivers Act" mandates states to publish a provider directory on their public website within 180 days. The directory must include primary and specialty care physicians and be updated annually. The "Medicaid Directory of Caregivers Act" requires states to publish a provider directory on their website within 180 days. The directory must include details such as the provider's name, specialty, address, and telephone number. For providers in a primary care case-management system, additional information on accepting new patients and cultural/linguistic capabilities must be included. The "Medicaid Directory of Caregivers Act" mandates states to publish a provider directory on their website within 180 days. The directory must include provider details like name, specialty, address, and phone number. For providers in a primary care case-management system, additional information on accepting new patients and cultural/linguistic capabilities must be included. Additionally, the Act specifies requirements for providers enrolled with the State agency to be listed in the directory. The Act mandates states to publish a provider directory on their website within 180 days, including provider details and requirements for enrollment. The amendment specifies criteria for providers to be listed in the directory based on payment received under the State plan in the preceding 12-month period. The Social Security Act requires individuals, other than Indians or Alaska Natives, enrolled in a Medicaid managed care organization to include prepaid health plans. State legislation may be needed for State plans under title XIX to meet additional requirements. State legislation may be required for State plans under title XIX to meet additional requirements imposed by recent amendments. Plans will not be considered non-compliant solely for failing to meet these requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter following the State legislature's session after the enactment of the amendments. If a State has a 2-year legislative session, each year will be considered a separate regular session.
